'''Big Maceo Merriweather''' (March 31, 1905 – February 23, 1953), known as '''Big Maceo''', was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] [[pianist]] and [[singer]], active in [[Chicago]] in the 1940s.<ref name="Music">{{cite book
| first= Paul
| last= Du Noyer
| year= 2003
| title= The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Flame Tree Publishing 
| location= Fulham, London
| isbn= 1-904041-96-5
| page= 181}}</ref>

==Career==
Born '''Major Merriweather''' (or '''Merewethe'''r) in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]],<ref name="all about"/> he was a self-taught pianist. In the 1920s he moved to [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]], [[Michigan]] to begin his music career. He moved to Chicago in 1941, where he made the acquaintance of [[Tampa Red]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher=Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 91
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Red introduced him to [[Lester Melrose]] of [[Bluebird Records]], who signed him to a [[recording contract]].<ref name="african american">[http://www.aaregistry.com/african_american_history/803/Big_Maceo_heavyhanded_piano_great_voice African American Registry biography]</ref>

His first [[gramophone record|record]] was "[[Worried Life Blues]]" (1941), which promptly became a blues [[hit record|hit]] and remained his signature piece. Other classic piano blues recordings such as "Chicago Breakdown", "Texas Stomp", and "[[List of songs about Detroit|Detroit Jump]]" followed.<ref name="african american"/> His piano style developed from players like [[Leroy Carr]] and [[Roosevelt Sykes]], as well as from the [[Boogie-woogie]] style of [[Meade Lux Lewis]] and [[Albert Ammons]]. He in turn influenced other musicians like [[Henry Gray (musician)|Henry Gray]], who credits Merriweather to helping him launch his career as a blues pianist.

His style had an impact on practically every post [[World War II]] blues pianist of note.<ref name="russell"/> His most famous song, "Worried Life Blues" is a staple of the blues repertoire, with [[musician|artists]] such as [[Eric Clapton]] featuring it regularly in [[concert]].<ref name="cascade">[http://www.cascadeblues.org/History/MaceoMerriweather.htm Cascadeblues.org biography]</ref> "Worried Life Blues" was in the first batch of songs inducted into the [[Blues Hall of Fame]] "Classic Blues Recordings - Singles or Albums Tracks" alongside "[[Call It Stormy Monday (But Tuesday Is Just as Bad)|Stormy Monday]]," '[[Sweet Home Chicago]]," "[[Dust My Broom]]," and "[[Hellhound On My Trail]]."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blues.org/halloffame/inductees.php4?ArtistId=406 |title=1983 Blues Hall Of Fame Inductees |accessdate=2008-08-29 |}}</ref>

He suffered a [[stroke]] in 1946<ref name="russell"/> and died of a heart attack on February 23, 1953 in [[Chicago]], and was interred at the [[Detroit Memorial Cemetery]] in [[Warren, Michigan]].<ref name="all about">[http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=4989 Allaboutjazz.com biography - accessed February 2008]</ref> 

His recordings for [[Bluebird Records|Bluebird]] were released in a [[double album]] set as ''Chicago Breakdown,'' in 1975. They have since been reissued on a variety of [[record label|labels]].<ref name="all about"/>

In 2002 he was [[posthumous recognition|posthumously]] inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame.

On May 3, 2008 the White Lake Blues Festival took place at the Howmet Playhouse Theater in [[Whitehall, Michigan]]. The event was organized by executive producer, Steve Salter, of the nonprofit organization ''Killer Blues'' to raise monies to honor Merriweather's unmarked grave with a headstone. The concert was a success, and a headstone was placed in June, 2008.
